The kinetic energy of the electron at point C can be calculated using the conservation of energy principle.
Since the electric field does not do any work in the direction of the initial velocity, the kinetic energy in that direction remains unchanged.
The kinetic energy in the perpendicular direction is due to the work done by the electric field.
The kinetic energy in the perpendicular direction can be calculated using the formula: KE_perp = 1/2 m v_perp^2
The perpendicular component of the velocity can be calculated using the angle of deflection: v_perp = v0 tan(θ)
Substituting the given values: v_perp = 4 × 10^6 × tan(30°) = 4 × 10^6 × 1/√3 ≈ 2.309 × 10^6 m/s
